verses.text: The men of Ephraim were called together and crossed over to Zaphon, and said to Jephthah, 'Why did you cross over to fight against the Ammonites and did not call us to go with you? We will burn your house down on you with fire.'
verses.comment: Ephraim's complaint is similar to their complaint to Gideon in Judges 8:1.

verses.text: Jephthah said to them, 'I and my people were in a great conflict with the Ammonites. When I called you, you did not save me from their hand.'
verses.comment: Jephthah refers to earlier interactions where Ephraim could have helped.

verses.text: 'When I saw that you would not help, I put my life in my hands and crossed over against the Ammonites, and the LORD gave them into my hand. Why have you come up to me today to fight against me?'
verses.comment: Literal rendering of 'put my life in my hands,' an idiom for risking one's life.

verses.text: Jephthah gathered all the men of Gilead and fought with Ephraim. The men of Gilead defeated Ephraim, because they said, 'You Gileadites are fugitives of Ephraim among the Ephraimites and among the Manassites.'
verses.comment: The insult 'fugitives of Ephraim' echoes tribal tensions.

verses.text: The Gileadites captured the crossings of the Jordan opposite Ephraim, and whenever a fugitive from Ephraim said, 'Let me cross over,' the men of Gilead would ask him, 'Are you an Ephraimite?' If he said, 'No,'
verses.comment: The 'crossings of the Jordan' refers to important river fords.

verses.text: then they would say to him, 'Say Shibboleth.' But he would say 'Sibboleth,' and could not pronounce it correctly. Then they seized him and killed him at the crossings of the Jordan. At that time, forty-two thousand of Ephraim fell.
verses.comment: Saying 'Shibboleth' tested their dialect; failing marked them as Ephraimite.

verses.text: Jephthah judged Israel for six years. Then Jephthah the Gileadite died and was buried in the cities of Gilead.
verses.comment: 'Cities of Gilead'—some Hebrew manuscripts and Septuagint say 'his city in Gilead'.

verses.text: After him, Ibzan of Bethlehem judged Israel.
verses.comment: Ibzan’s origin is likely Bethlehem in Judah, though some suggest Bethlehem in Zebulun.

verses.text: He had thirty sons, and thirty daughters whom he sent outside, and he brought in thirty daughters from outside for his sons. He judged Israel for seven years.
verses.comment: Ibzan’s large family and marriages show his social influence.

verses.text: Ibzan died and was buried at Bethlehem.
After him, Elon the Zebulunite judged Israel, and he judged Israel for ten years.
verses.comment: Elon’s brief account follows the formula for minor judges.

verses.text: Elon the Zebulunite died and was buried at Aijalon in the land of Zebulun.
verses.comment: Aijalon’s location matches the tribal inheritance in Joshua.

verses.text: After him, Abdon son of Hillel the Pirathonite judged Israel.
verses.comment: Pirathon is in the territory of Ephraim (see 1 Chron. 7:22).

verses.text: He had forty sons and thirty grandsons, who rode on seventy donkeys. He judged Israel for eight years.
verses.comment: Riding donkeys signifies status and wealth.

verses.text: Abdon son of Hillel the Pirathonite died and was buried at Pirathon in the land of Ephraim, in the hill country of the Amalekites.
verses.comment: The 'hill country of the Amalekites' refers to an area the Amalekites previously occupied.
